'''Anti-terrorism Act, 2009''' is a Bangladeshi legislative act that is designed to specifically target terrorism.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anti Terrorism Act, 2009|url=http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/bangladesh/document/papers/AntiTerrorism_Act2009.pdf|website=satp.org|accessdate=30 September 2017}}</ref>
==History== The Law was formulated by the Grand Alliance government led by [[Bangladesh Awami League]] in 2009. The law was given retrospective effect from 11 June 2008. The law was designed to target terrorists and financial institutes used by them.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ali|first1=AMM Shawkat|title=Anti-terrorism Act, 2009|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Anti-terrorism_Act,_2009|website=en.banglapedia.org|publisher=Banglapedia|accessdate=30 September 2017|language=en}}</ref> In 2012 amendment changed the highest punishment under the act to death penalty. In 2013 another amendment allowed for social media content to be entered as evidence.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bangladesh: New Amendment to Anti-Terrorism Act gags Freedom of Expression|url=https://www.fidh.org/en/region/asia/bangladesh/bangladesh-new-amendment-to-anti-terrorism-act-gags-freedom-of-expression-13457|website=Worldwide Movement for Human Rights|accessdate=30 September 2017|language=fr-FR}}</ref>
==Criticism== Human Rights group, Odhikar, has called for the law to be repelled describing the act as a total for repression on those opposed to the government.<ref>{{cite web|title=Odhikar’s concern about Anti-Terrorism Act 2009|url=http://odhikar.org/odhikars-concern-about-anti-terrorism-act-2009/|website=odhikar.org|accessdate=30 September 2017}}</ref> Cases under this act need government approval for trials to begin, which are sometimes delayed. Thus effectively placing the cases in legal limbo.<ref>{{cite web|title=27 anti-terror cases stuck|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/27-anti-terror-cases-stuck-1258096|website=The Daily Star|accessdate=30 September 2017|language=en|date=23 July 2016}}</ref>

{{No footnotes|date=February 2016}} [[File:Arizona flagstone.jpg|thumb|Arizona Flagstone in winter]] [[Image:Arizonaflagstonewinter.jpg|thumb|Buckskin Arizona Flagstone]] '''Arizona flagstone''' is composed of rounded grains of [[quartz]] which are cemented by [[silica]]. Other minerals are present, mostly as thin seams of clay, [[mica]], secondary [[calcite]], and [[gypsum]]. Arizona flagstone is mainly quarried from the [[Coconino National Forest|Coconino]] and [[Prescott National Forest]]s.
Although [[flagstone]] and dimension stone are quarried from all over the state of [[Arizona]], the town of [[Ash Fork, Arizona]], is well known as the center of production and has proclaimed itself "The Flagstone Capital of the World". Extensive outcrops of Arizona flagstone are also found in [[Mohave County, Arizona|Mohave]], [[Coconino County, Arizona|Coconino]], [[Yavapai County, Arizona|Yavapai]], [[Navajo County, Arizona|Navajo]], [[Apache County, Arizona|Apache]], and [[Gila County, Arizona|Gila]] counties.

page.title: Australian greyhound racing live baiting scandal

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} The '''Australian greyhound racing live baiting scandal''' is a series of events that occurred in at least three [[Australia]]n [[States and territories of Australia|states]] where [[Bait (luring substance)|live baiting]] of [[greyhound racing|racing greyhounds]] was exposed on [[ABC (Australian TV channel)|ABC TV]] and in ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''. On 16 February 2015, the Australian television current affairs program ''[[Four Corners (Australian TV program)|Four Corners]]'' revealed the use of live [[piglet (animal)|piglet]]s, [[Phalangeriformes|possums]] and [[rabbit]]s to train racing greyhounds had been occurring over some years, despite self-regulatory efforts to address the issue.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meldrum-Hanna|first1=Caro|author2=Clark, Sam|title=Making a Killing|url=http://www.abc.net.au/4corners/stories/2015/02/16/4178920.htm|website=abc.net.au|accessdate=18 February 2015|date=16 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Then and Now: 12 Months of Reform|url=http://www.grnsw.com.au/uploads/GRNSW-infographic-Then-%26-Now-A3-2.2.pdf|publisher=Greyhound Racing NSW|date=February 2016|accessdate=5 September 2016}}</ref> The revelation led to suspensions, inquiries, widespread condemnation of the practice, and, following an inquiry, to the banning of greyhound racing in [[New South Wales]] from July 2017, and consequently, the [[Australian Capital Territory]] as well. The NSW ban was reversed on 11 October 2016, with conditions.
==Background== {{further|Greyhound racing in Australia}} [[Greyhound racing]] is an organized, competitive sport in which [[greyhound|greyhound dogs]] are raced around a track, chasing a mechanical lure over a fixed distance. Historically, the sport is based on the principle of [[Hare coursing|coursing]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Genders, Roy |year=1981 |title=The Encyclopaedia of Greyhound Racing |publisher=Pelham Books Ltd |isbn=0-7207-1106-1 |page= }}</ref> It is a legalised form of [[gambling]] in many jurisdictions. Some greyhound trainers believe that greyhounds will chase better, and hence have a greater chance of winning the race, if they have chased and caught a live animal during training.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} The live bait animal is either attached to the mechanical lure, dragged in front of the greyhound, or thrown to it. The greyhound will often maim or kill the bait animal, resulting in death.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}}
==Controversy== The greyhound industry and the law provide harsh penalties for the use of live baits in training.<ref>{{cite web|title=ANIMAL WELFARE PENALTY GUIDELINES|url=http://www.grv.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/Animal-Welfare-Penalty-Guidelines-July-1-2014.pdf|website=grv.org.au|accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Is the use of live baits and lures in greyhound racing illegal?|url=http://kb.rspca.org.au/Is-the-use-of-live-baits-and-lures-in-greyhound-racing-and-other-dog-racing-illegal_241.html|website=rspca.org.au|accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref> Nevertheless, accusations of live baiting in the Australian greyhound industry have arisen from time to time.<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Brien|first1=Natalie|title=Vets claim live animals used as bait to train greyhounds|url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/animals/vets-claim-live-animals-used-as-bait-to-train-greyhounds-20131123-2y2hg.html|accessdate=18 February 2015|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=24 November 2013}}</ref>
On 16 February 2015, ''Four Corners'' exposed live baiting on training tracks in [[Queensland]], [[New South Wales]] and [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. The program included graphic surveillance footage, filmed by pro-animal activists, that showed various small animals being tied to mechanical lures where they were chased, caught and attacked by greyhounds for up to 30 minutes. Some animals had young taken and given to the dogs. The program also included interviews with many leading greyhound trainers and administrators who denied the practice of live baiting; some of them were subsequently shown to be involved in the live baiting.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Olding|first1=Rachel|title=Allegations of systemic cheating and live baiting within greyhound racing industry uncovered by Four Corners|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/allegations-of-systemic-cheating-and-live-baiting-within-greyhound-racing-industry-uncovered-by-four-corners-20150217-13gi30.html|accessdate=19 February 2015|work=smh.com.au|date=17 February 2015}}</ref>
The program’s graphic content drew immediate and widespread criticism from animal protection groups<ref>{{cite web|title=Piglets, possums and rabbits tortured in sadistic greyhound training 'rituals'|url=http://www.animalsaustralia.org/take_action/greyhound-racing-live-baiting-exposed|website=animalsaustralia.org|accessdate=19 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Belot|first1=Henry|title=RSPCA calls for tighter regulation of greyhound industry|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/rspca-calls-for-tighter-regulation-of-greyhound-industry-20150217-13gu65.html|accessdate=19 February 2015|date=17 February 2015}}</ref> and the wider community.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Casey|first1=Brendan|title=Public outrage over live baiting in greyhound racing following ABC Four Corners investigation|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/public-outrage-over-live-baiting-in-greyhound-racing-following-abc-four-corners-investigation/story-fni0fit3-1227222407215|accessdate=19 February 2015|work=[[herald Sun]]|location=Melbourne}}</ref>
National Party member of parliament and minister [[Barnaby Joyce]] criticised activists who apparently trespassed to record video of live baiting by trainers.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Owens|first1=Jared|author2=Cormick, Brendan|title=Barnaby Joyce criticises activists in greyhound live-bait expose|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/barnaby-joyce-criticises-activists-in-greyhound-live-bait-expose/story-e6frg6nf-1227223167503|accessdate=19 February 2015|work=[[The Australian]]|date=17 February 2015}}</ref>
==Reactions==
=== Australian Capital Territory === * After announcement of the intended NSW ban, Chief Minister [[Andrew Barr]] stated that greyhound racing would be banned in the ACT<ref name="can-times-ban">{{cite news |last1=Belot|first1=Henry |title=ACT government says it can no longer support greyhound racing after NSW decision |url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/act-government-under-pressure-to-ban-greyhound-racing-after-nsw-decision-20160707-gq0gz1.html |accessdate=21 July 2016 |work=Canberra Times |date=11 July 2016}}</ref>
===New South Wales=== *Five registered participants were immediately stood down<ref>{{cite news|title=Greyhound Racing NSW stands down five over live baiting allegations|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/greyhound-racing-nsw-stands-down-five-over-live-baiting-allegations-20150213-13dxvq.html|accessdate=19 February 2015|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=13 February 2015}}</ref> *The Greyhound Racing NSW board was dismissed<ref>{{cite web|title=Greyhound Racing NSW board dismissed amid revelations of live baiting|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-02-19/entire-board-of-nsw-greyhound-racing-dismissed/6144352|website=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |location=Australia |accessdate=19 February 2015}}</ref> and the Chief Executive Officer, Brent Hogan, stood aside *Former [[High Court of Australia]] judge [[Michael McHugh (judge)|Michael McHugh]] was appointed to lead a review of the industry<ref>{{cite news|last1=Roots|first1=Chris|title=Greyhound racing live baiting revelations should be a turning point for industry, says new chief executive|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/horseracing/greyhound-racing-live-baiting-revelations-should-be-a-turning-point-for-industry-says-new-chief-executive-20150219-13jq2s.html|accessdate=19 February 2015|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=18 February 2015}}</ref> *Following the [[Special Commission of Inquiry into the Greyhound Racing Industry in NSW|McHugh inquiry]], the Premier announced on 7 July 2016 that greyhound racing would be banned in NSW from 1 July 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/nsw-premier-mike-baird-announces-ban-on-greyhound-racing-after-special-commission-of-inquiry-20160707-gq0fw3.html|title=NSW Premier Mike Baird announces ban on greyhound racing after Special Commission of Inquiry|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=7 July 2016 |access-date=7 July 2016}}</ref>
On 2 August a rally opposing the ban was held at [[Hyde Park, Sydney]].<ref name="guard-ban-protest">{{cite news |title=Hundreds protest greyhound racing ban as Mike Baird seeks to calm MPs |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/aug/02/nsw-liberal-mp-attacks-mike-baird-over-greyhound-racing-ban |accessdate=10 August 2016 |work=The Guardian |agency=Australian Associated Press |date=1 August 2016}}</ref> On 5 August 2016 an alliance of greyhound racing groups took the matter to the [[Supreme Court of NSW]] in pursuit of a declaration that the inquiry report was invalid.<ref name="guardian-ban-challenge">{{cite news|title=Greyhound racing ban: industry alliance launches challenge in supreme court|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/jul/29/greyhound-racing-ban-industry-alliance-launches-challenge-in-supreme-court|accessdate=10 August 2016|work=The Guardian|agency=Australian Associated Press|date=29 July 2016}}</ref> After running newspaper advertisements supporting the ban, the NSW Government was criticised by Brenton Scott, the chief executive of the Greyhound Breeders, Owners and Trainers Association. [[Luke Foley]], NSW [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] leader, led his party's opposition to the ban.<ref name="guard-anti-ads">{{cite news |last1=Davey|first1=Melissa |title=Anti-greyhound racing ads a misuse of NSW public funds, says industry |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/aug/01/anti-greyhound-racing-ads-a-misuse-of-nsw-public-funds-says-industry |accessdate=10 August 2016 |work=The Guardian |date=1 August 2016}}</ref> In August 2016 legislation was introduced into the NSW Legislative Assembly and three [[National Party of Australia|National]] MPs [[crossed the floor]] to vote against the government; with one [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]] MP abstaining from the vote. Despite these protests, the legislation passed the lower house.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-08-24/greyhound-racing-prohibition-bill-passed-by-nsw-parliament/7779222 |author=Fogarty, Siobhan |title=Greyhound racing ban: Nationals MPs cross floor as bill passes Parliament |work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |location=Australia |date=24 August 2016 |accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/greyhound-racing-banned-after-bill-passes-nsw-parliament-20160823-gqzj0f.html |author=Nicholls, Sean |title=Greyhound racing banned after bill passes NSW parliament |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=Australia |date=24 August 2016 |accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref>
On 11 October 2016 the reversal of the NSW ban was announced, with several conditions.<ref name="abc-backflip">{{cite news |last1=Glanville|first1=Brigid |last2=Gerathy|first2=Sarah |title=NSW Premier confirms backflip on greyhound racing ban |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-10-11/greyhound-ban-baird-government-confirms-backflip/7921000 |accessdate=11 October 2016 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=11 October 2016}}</ref> As of March 2017, legislation to reverse the ban has not come before the NSW Parliament and there has been no greyhound racing scheduled in NSW beyond 30 June 2017.
===Queensland=== *13 trainers are under investigation; 6 have been suspended *Macro Meats withdrew its sponsorship of the sport *[[Jonathan Brown (Australian footballer)|Jonathan Brown]] resigned as an ambassador *One trainer was removed from the Racing Queensland Hall of Fame<ref>{{cite news|last1=Newman|first1=Beth|title=Racing Queensland says greyhound sponsor withdrawal 'understandable'|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/racing-queensland-says-greyhound-sponsor-withdrawal-understandable-20150218-13ilyk.html|accessdate=19 February 2015|work=smh.com.au|date=19 February 2015}}</ref> *The racing industry integrity officer was stood down<ref>{{cite news|last1=Oberhardt|first1=Mark|title=Queensland greyhound racing's integrity officer stood down|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/queensland-greyhound-racings-integrity-officer-stood-down-20150222-13lq2h.html|accessdate=23 February 2015|work=smh.com.au|date=22 February 2015}}</ref> *All Racing Queensland boards dismissed<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/qld-govt-to-abolish-all-racing-boards/story-e6frfku9-1227379217658|title=Qld government sacks racing boards|first1=Nathan|last1=Paull|first2=Marty|last2=Silk|agency=AAP|date=2 June 2015}}</ref> * Tom Noble, on whose race track the live baiting was occurring, pleaded guilty and was sentenced on 6 September 2016 to 15 counts of serious animal cruelty. Serious Animal cruelty in the QLD Criminal Code attracts a maximum penalty of 7 years and yet Noble only received a 3 year wholly suspended sentence. The QLD Attorney-General, Yvette D'Ath, announced her decision to appeal the sentence on the grounds it was manifestly inadequate. Tom Noble appeared in the appeals court on the 17th March, 2017. The decision is yet to be announced.<ref>http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/dog-trainer-who-used-live-piglets-possums-should-be-jailed-appeals-court-20170317-gv0ujn.html</ref><ref>http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/logan-greyhound-track-draws-200strong-protest-20141011-114s1x.html</ref>
===South Australia=== * Greyhound Racing SA immediately announced that anyone found to be engaging in the practice would be banished from the sport and prosecuted where possible.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/sport/superracing/greyhounds-racing-sa-takes-tough-stance-on-live-baiting/story-fnii0osj-1227222225704 |title=Greyhounds Racing SA takes tough stance on live baiting |first=Tom |last=Biddington |work=The Advertiser |date=17 February 2015 |publisher=News Limited |accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> The chief executive said that he had no evidence that live baiting was happening in South Australia but "we take little comfort from that because our monitoring processes aren't dissimilar from the eastern seaboard... We shouldn't be satisfied that our monitoring is working – I think we need to accept that, quite clearly".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://indaily.com.au/news/2015/02/17/greyhound-cruelty-live-baiting-happening-sa/ |title= Greyhound cruelty: Live baiting "happening in SA" |first=David |last=Washington |date=17 February 2015 |work=IN Daily |publisher=Solstice Media |accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> The relevant state government ministers, [[RSPCA Australia|RSPCA]], [[South Australia Police|police]] and Greyhound Racing SA met to consider a response, including possible changes to legislation to facilitate investigation and be tougher to prevent live baiting.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/sport/superracing/racing-minister-leon-bignell-will-not-turn-back-on-industry/story-fndpsebm-1227232388949 |title=Racing minister Leon Bignell will not turn back on industry |date=20 February 2015 |publisher=News Limited |accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref>
===Tasmania=== * The state government indicated a parliamentary inquiry would be held into the sport. In addition the states Chief Veterinarian and Director of Racing launched a joint inquiry.<ref>{{cite news|title=State Government puts greyhound racing industry on notice|url=http://www.themercury.com.au/sport/local-sport/state-government-puts-greyhound-racing-industry-on-notice/story-fnj92b0f-1227243660650|accessdate=1 March 2015|publisher=The Mercury|date=1 March 2015}}</ref>
===Victoria=== *The Victorian Government announced two separate investigations<ref>{{cite news|title=Greyhound racing: Victorian Integrity Commissioner says Four Corners live baiting revelations a shock|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-02-17/greyhound-live-baiting-victorian-government-two-investigations/6124754|accessdate=19 February 2015|work=abc.net.au}}</ref> *15 trainers have been suspended pending an investigation, including former administrators and a Trainer of the Year<ref>{{cite web|title=More greyhound trainers suspended in Vic|url=http://www.9news.com.au/national/2015/02/19/18/11/more-greyhound-trainers-suspended-in-vic|website=9news.com.au |accessdate=19 February 2015}}</ref> *The chairman of Greyhound Racing Victoria resigned<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lerner|first1=Ronny|title=Greyhound Racing Victoria chairman Peter Caillard resigns in wake of live-baiting scandal|url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/greyhound-racing-victoria-chairman-peter-caillard-resigns-in-wake-of-livebaiting-scandal-20150223-13mmi6.html|accessdate=23 February 2015|work=smh.com.au|date=23 February 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
